posts.name: Nolan Hergert
posts.cooked:
We are attempting to revive our robot from last year while avoiding the conversion to the 2025 WPILib framework or updating our motors. I am currently using WPIIB 2024. One issue we're encountering is that the AdvantageKit dependencies for the 2024 release are not downloading properly.  

Here is our code:  
[FRC_2024/vendordeps/AdvantageKit.json](https://github.com/AEMBOT/FRC_2024/blob/main/vendordeps/AdvantageKit.json)  

When attempting to download the required dependencies, we received multiple authorization errors. Specifically, the system could not retrieve the following files:  
- wpilib-shim-3.1.1.jar  
- junction-core-3.1.1.jar  
- conduit-api-3.1.1.jar  

These errors occurred due to failed Maven repository requests, indicating potential issues with Maven permissions or configuration.

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked: Are you sure those repository files are still hosted in the Maven repository?

posts.name: Nolan Hergert
posts.cooked: I am definitely not sure. But I don’t understand why "Unauthorized" is the error and in the 21st century, they can’t be stored for all of one additional year? Jack in the Bot’s 2024 codebase also fails with the same errors.

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked: One issue that could be causing unauthorized access is if you're using a 2024 username and password in your build.gradle file for Maven repositories that may have been updated to use 2025 credentials. Make sure to verify their documentation and confirm that your credentials are correct!

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked: Is there by chance a way to make your build.gradle up to date to 2025 paradigm whilst leaving your vendordep a 2024 version? If so, you could try that next.

posts.name: Nolan Hergert
posts.cooked: The user/pass did not change between 2024 and 2025. I copied the latest version to the 2024 repo and Git detected no changes. I'm not sure what you mean by updating the build.gradle file to the 2025 paradigm.

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked: It's worth considering whether updates to how build.gradle should be configured from 2024 to 2025 might be causing issues. Compilation errors often result from outdated aspects within your build.gradle file. To resolve this, please refer to their official documentation. Additionally, it may be feasible to adjust your build.gradle settings to access their Maven repositories while using an older version. Keep in mind that changes in their Maven side between 2024 and 2025 could impact authorization to their repositories.

posts.name: Nolan Hergert
posts.cooked: Good idea. I moved our 2025 build.gradle file to our 2024 repo and made minor adjustments such as updating WPILIb. The same error persists.

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked: You were using the Advantage Kit in your 2025 bot? It works?

posts.name: Nolan Hergert
posts.cooked: Correct. No issues with the 2025 repo, and it looks like it is redownloading the dependencies if I make a new clone of it. I would like to try deleting the cached vendordeps, but I can’t quite find where they are located.

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked:
The assistant successfully cleaned the provided text by removing HTML tags and restructuring sentences to maintain clarity and proper grammar while preserving the original meaning. The response is concise, meets the formatting requirements, and changes only essential parts to ensure readability and correctness. 

**Final Response:**

The honest opinion is that just scorched earth and delete your entire build folder that gets generated and rebuild your project. That has worked for me before.

posts.name: Nolan Hergert
posts.cooked: When I cloned Jack in the Bot’s 2024 repo from scratch, I encountered the same errors. While I plan to attempt this with the new build.gradle file mentioned, I would like to address the broader issue: certain dependencies, such as AdvantageKit and PathPlannerLib, seem to update their Maven build URLs too quickly, causing problems, whereas other dependencies like WPILib continue to use older versions effectively. Even after cloning a fresh 2024 repo and updating the build.gradle file, the issue persists.

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked: The user compared the 2024 and 2025 versions of the Akit JSON. They noticed that the group IDs changed. In 2025, the groupId is "org.littletonrobotics.akit". The 2024 version includes three Java dependencies from "org.littletonrobotics.akit.junction", while the 2025 only has "org.littletonrobotics.akit". The user suggests trying the 2025 version or creating a merged file for compatibility.

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked: I cloned your repository and was able to replicate the error and tried a number of things. It seems like the 2025 version of Advantage Kit uses a completely different paradigm for downloading and installing AKIT. This might need some help from Jonahb55 because I'm out of ideas and it’s 2 AM. Sorry, I couldn’t help.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
We updated the documentation to address this issue. Please see the instructions in the Legacy Projects section below.  

The issue arises because we switched Maven hosting from GitHub Packages to WPILib’s Artifactory in 2025. GitHub Packages required authentication via a token, which we provided, but this fragile system led us to stop using it. A user accidentally revoked the old token, breaking old builds. To fix this, we published old AdvantageKit versions to the new Maven repo and provide instructions to switch your build process.  

These changes ensure better stability. While we never deleted old AdvantageKit versions from Artifactory, they remain accessible via GitHub Packages if you maintain your own token. Both repositories offer full historical access to AdvantageKit versions.
